John Smith wrote:

> --- Chris Dollin <kers@...> wrote:
> > Neither.
> >
> > assertTrue(true) looks daft, and the comment won't
> > stop style critics.
> >
> > I have an empty method in my TestBase class(es),
> > called `pass`, which
> > I call. It expresses intent and shuts up the local
> > critic.
>
> If this would be recommended by the JUnit inventors,
> they would have added a method like pass() or
> succeed() in their class TestCase I think.

That's quite an assumption!  No matter how good Erich and Kent may be, I 
don't think they can think of everything (thus a version 3.8.1 instead 
of the it-is-perfect-and-nothing-else-needs-to-be-added-1.0 version). ;)

>
> To call a method which does nothing, makes no sense in
> my eyes. It silences Checkstyle, but is nonsense
> nevertheless. Of course methods like pass() or
> assertTrue(true) are a kind of documentation. But this
> is also a kind of documentation, and can be used
> everywhere, not just for a test:
>
This may be opening a can of worms, nevertheless... No-op methods are 
not always unneccessary.  Consider the case of a TemplateMethod where an 
implementor of the template steps may not need to do anything at a 
particular point.  I might be able to think of other cases where I have 
intentionally called no-op methods, but they aren't popping to mind just 
now.

Besides that, a method like pass() IS intention-revealing.

-- 
Jason Rogers
